attributes.title: Stock Verifcation
attributes.description:
Findings;

·       A stock take was conducted on 08 February 2025 to establish whether the physical stocks were matching with the stock book balance generated from SAP system and whether internal controls on stocks were effective.

·       The physical stock count revealed minimal variances when compared with the system's recorded balance for almost all stock items. However, notable discrepancies were observed in the following categories:

ü  Packing Materials: Variance of +567 pieces.

ü  Bread Stock: White Bread: Variance of - 484 pieces & Brown Bread a variance of -33 pieces.

The table below illustrates the findings:
attributes.recommendation: ·       Regularly audit both physical and SAP inventories to ensure accuracy. Focus particularly on items with larger variances, like the bread stock.
attributes.effect: The discrepancies in bread stock and poly bags are a concern. If these issues persist, they could impact production and fulfilment capabilities, indicating weak controls.

value: The significant variation in bread stock is a result of negligence. A deduction will be made to recover the shortfall in bread stock, as identified during the audit.
Variation of stock shall be checked and strong controls maintained.

In the prior Audit, Physical stock was verified on 17/10/24 at Likoni 1 branch showed raw materials stock shortfalls i.e. 125kg of white flour, 7bags of white bread ingredients and 9bags of brown bread ingredients that were worth Kes. 32,697.20 And were not surcharged. Bread stock taken on the same date showed bread surplus stocks of 4,039pcs (400g) worth Kes. 216,086.50
Previous
A stock take exercise was conducted on 8th February 2025 to assess the effectiveness of internal controls that are put in place i.e. Raw Materials, Finished Goods, Polybags & Miscellaneous.
Stock had minimal variances.
Operations/Production Department
Ensuring Strong Internal Controls are Put in Place.

attributes.title: Bread Weight Check
attributes.description:
Findings;

·       We conducted Bread weight spot checks on 8 February 2025 on packed bread ready to be dispatched to the market to determine whether the bread dispatched to the market meets the required weight standards.

·       From the selected sample, bread underweights were noted in

     Overweight Products:

ü  200g WB Dough: 38% overweight

ü  400g White Dough: 38% overweight

ü  200g WB: 27% overweight

     

      Underweight Products:

ü  400g WB: 13% underweight

ü  400g WB Dough: 16% Underweight

ü  800g WB: 9% underweight
attributes.recommendation: Strict adherence to established weight standards for bread production to help maintain consistency in product quality and prevent discrepancies in weights.
attributes.effect:
·       Overweight or underweight products can lead to cost inefficiencies, especially if the consumer is paying for a product that doesn't match the expected weight. Underweight bread also can affect brand reputation and can led to loss of customers.

For dough varieties, a consistently overweight product could be an issue for packaging leading to inefficiencies and waste in production.

value: This is noted more effort will be in place to minimize the percentage noted in that period of audit

·       The higher number of underweight products is attributed to the extended period that bread remains before being packed after the cooling stage, resulting in moisture loss. This will be worked on going forward.

Strict supervision will be done to ensure the set dividing range is achieved to avoid underweight and overweight dough.

·       In the prior audit, we noted the following   under weights bread.

                     4W – 5%
Previous
Bread Weight is done for all the varieties.
Compliance was met, with no cases of underweight bread.
Operations/Production Department
To establish whether the branch adheres to weights and measures standards.

attributes.title: Bread Damages Analysis
attributes.description:
·       We reviewed the damages for the period 1 to 31 January 2025 to determine if there were instances of excess damages beyond the set standard limits of 0.25% of total production for production damages and 0.3% of total sales for market damages.

·       It was observed that both production-related damages and market-related damages were within the established limits, indicating that the damage levels are being effectively managed and controlled as illustrated below;
attributes.recommendation: To adhere to the set quality control parameters within the production process to minimize production damages.
attributes.effect:
·       Production Damages are at 0.20%, which is below the target of 0.25% by 0.05%, indicating effective production processes and a low level of waste or errors.

·       Market Damages are at 0.21%, also below the target of 0.3% by 0.09%, suggesting good distribution and handling processes, minimizing damage during transport or sale.

No extra damages were converted to 400g loaves, indicating that damages did not significantly impact the overall production or sales.

value: Regular quality checks should be maintained to keep these numbers within the desired range.
The production damages will be maintained.
In the prior Audit, market damage rate was 0.1% and production damage rate 0.2%.
Previous
The test was conducted to determine the extent of damages produced during production and those replaced as market damages and find out if they were within the set limits.
The production and market damages were within the set limit.
Operations/Production Department
Ensuring controlled bread damages.

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

·       An analysis of mixing charts and summaries was done for a period of 31 days from 1 January to 31 January 2025 to determine if the raw materials usage were as per the set BOM and if the set production standards were achieved.

·       An analysis was also performed to verify if there were any significant variances between the mixing chart summary and the SAP system. Appendix2

·       The total number of loaves produced, as recorded in the mixing chart for January 2025, was 626,914.50, which exceeds the SAP forecast of 626,527 by 387.50 loaves.

Appendix2

·       The table below shows a summarised findings of the mixing chart analysis.
attributes.recommendation: ·       The branch should work towards achieving the set production target and Yield.
attributes.effect:
·       Production target was below the set target, and this indicated that the branch’s production capacity was underutilized by 19.82% which could imply lost sales.

The yield per bag is 200.16 pieces of bread, slightly below the expected 201 pieces per bag. While this is a small deviation, it may indicate room for improvement in production efficiency, which could potentially lead to an increase in the overall output without additional resource consumption.

value:
·       On 29th and 30th January, only 2 shifts were scheduled, resulting in lower-than-expected production during these days.

We collaborate with the sales team to secure additional orders and drive increased production.
Production target achievement was hindered by less orders.
In the previous audit, it was noted that there was a variance of (639.5) between the Mixing Chart and SAP.
Previous
Comparison of manual mixing charts and the SAP mixing charts was done from 1st to 28th February 2025 to find out Manual Mixing Chart was matching with SAP System
Set Yield, Consumption was observed apart from set production target which was not achieved due to less orders and cutting down production.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure the set Yield, Consumption of Raw Materials and Production Bags is achieved

attributes.title: Production Efficiency Analysis
attributes.description:
·       Production efficiency was calculated for a period of 31 days from 1 January 2025 to 31 January 2024. The aim was to determine if the production workers hired were achieving the set production efficiency of 4.50 bags.

·       It was noted that the production efficiency was 4.47 bags per production worker, which was slightly below the set efficiency level. The hiring of 5 extra workers may not result in significant gains in production efficiency, as the company was able to achieve 99% of the target efficiency with the current workforce.

A summary of the analysis is shown below;
attributes.recommendation: ·       Although the production deficit is minor, efforts should be made to improve the efficiency of the production process to achieve the target KPI of 4.50 bags per worker. This could involve optimizing workflows, or addressing any operational bottlenecks.
attributes.effect:
·       The production target efficiency was slightly below the set target.

Hiring an additional 5 workers has a cost implication of KES 5,433.

value: There was a minor deficit in production, but I will monitor the situation to ensure that the production target is fully achieved.
There was production cut done on 29th and 30th January. This affected the efficiency.
In the previous audit, it was noted that the production efficiency was 4.4 per production worker.
Previous

This test was conducted to determine if set production and packing efficiency was adhered to. Low efficiency would indicate increased production costs. Standard production efficiency is 4.5bags per staff.
Production efficiency was slightly below the target (4.47).
Operations/Production Department
Ensuring set production efficiency is adhered to.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
Findings;

·       Packing Efficiency was computed for period of 31 days from 1 January 2025 to 31 January 2025 to determine whether the set company standard of 97 crates per slicer was being achieved.

·       The findings revealed that the average slicing efficiency for the period was 84.45 crates per slicer.

·       The table below illustrates the findings;-
attributes.recommendation: The branch together with the sales team should ensure enough sales orders are secured to support optimal production levels.
attributes.effect:
·       The slicing efficiency target of 97 crates per slicer was not achieved due to lower production at the branch, which resulted from reduced order volumes.

Hiring 61 extra slicers cost the company KES 55, 632 in additional labour costs. The 87% efficiency achieved is still below the ideal packing target, which suggests the company did not fully optimize the use of the extra slicers hired.

value: This is well noted more effort will be done for the achievement of 97 plus crates.
We shall work together with sales team to ensure we secure enough sales orders.
No previous findings.
Previous

·Get the total production for the 3shift of previous day, 1shift, and 2shift of the current day, then less FOC, Less Production damages, less oven damages and less deductions (short or bread)

=Loaves to be packed.
The slicing efficiency was not  achieved.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure set efficiency of 97 crates per slicer is achieved.

attributes.title: Mini shop spot check
attributes.description:
Findings:

·       A spot check was conducted in the mini shop on 11 February 2025 to assess whether the operations were being carried out in accordance with the established standards.

·       The physical quantities of various varieties were compared to the DDS balance, and the variance was calculated to identify any discrepancies.

·       It was noted that there were variances between the physical quantities and the DDS balances for certain varieties as illustrated below;
attributes.recommendation: A detailed audit of stock movement and better tracking measures should be implemented to reduce any negative variances.
attributes.effect:
The 4W, 4BT and Bread Rolls at Likoni 1, shows a large negative variance, indicating a significant shortfall.

Positive variances in Mtongwe's 4W (+2) and Likoni 1's 2W (+9) suggest slight excess quantities, which may indicate overstocking.

value: Noted
We shall maintain controls at the mini shops.
No previous findings.
Previous
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Vehicle Mileage & Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings;

·       The purpose of this audit was to assess and analyse the fuel consumption of the branch sales vehicle for the period from 1 January to 31 January 2025. The primary objectives were to evaluate compliance with fuel efficiency standards, identify any areas of inefficiency, and recommend strategies for reducing fuel consumption and associated costs.
attributes.recommendation: The management should maintain the strong controls on fuel consumption of vehicles.
attributes.effect: The internal controls governing the fuel consumption of vehicles are effective.

value: Manager always advised to keep records and tracking on mileage book, this will be maintained.
We will maintain good controls.
No previous findings.
Previous
The exercise was carried out to determine if fuel consumption quantities by sales vans was at par with those provided on the revised permanent file.
Effective fuel consumption
Operations/Production Department
Ensuring that all sales vans fuel consumption is as per set standards.

attributes.title: Cash Verification
attributes.description:
Finding;

·       Verification of cash held at the cash office was done on 11 February 2025, to confirm if the cash held by the cashier tallied with book records and whether the set cash operation standards were adhered to.
attributes.recommendation: Adherence to the company's cash control policies is essential, and proper reconciliation procedures must be conducted to ensure accuracy and integrity of the cash records.
attributes.effect: ·       The cash balance seems to be accurate, with only a small discrepancy of  KES -48.06

value: Minimal variance but we will strengthen the cash controls to mitigate any potential risk.
Cash control procedures will be enhanced to ensure improved accuracy.

·       In the prior audit

report,

we noted a

minimal variance

of +1.72
Previous
Physical cash was verified on 08/02/2025 to check whether cash counted matched that on SAP balances.
Minimal cash variance suggest effective controls were put in place.
Operations/Production Department
Ensuring Cash Controls are strong.

attributes.title: Debtors Analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of the debt balance as at 09 February 2025 was performed to identify any occurrences of bad debts or unresolved balances by route.

·       During the audit, it was noted that there were no significant outstanding balances.
attributes.recommendation: The sales and operations teams should continue maintaining effective controls over debtors. Additionally, timely follow-up should be conducted to ensure the clearance of the minimal outstanding balance at Minishop -Kariokor.
attributes.effect: The absence of significant outstanding debts suggests that the company’s credit control processes are functioning well, and there is no immediate financial exposure from overdue receivables.

value: I will continue to regularly monitor the debtors.
We will maintain debtor’s controls.
No previous findings.
Previous
Operations/Production Department
To ensure there is no Outstanding Balances.
